Key Arguments: The Bill interferes with the right to freedom of speech, which is fundamental to Australian democracy.
The Bill is inconsistent with Australia's international human rights obligations, particularly under the UN Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
The Bill lacks adequate provisions to protect freedom of expression and does not meet international law standards for interfering with this right.
The definition of 'harm' in the Bill is vague and could be used to suppress legitimate speech on important social issues.
Notable Quotes: This Bill directly interferes with our rights to freedom of speech which Australians are privileged to hold.
The vague and ideological definition of 'harm' in the Bill risks it being weaponised to shut down legitimate speech on pressing social issues.
